Biomass-derived chemicals show great promise as an alternative resource for the replacement of fossil fuel-derived chemicals. The double dehydration of sorbitol produces isosorbide, which is an important chemical building platform and a component in food, pharmaceuticals, and plasticizers. Homogeneous catalysts are used to perform this reaction due to their good performance, but they also exhibit some drawbacks. Therefore, in this study, the sulfonic acid resin Purolite CT269 was used as a heterogeneous catalyst to study isosorbide production. The reaction was carried out with a 4.43 wt.% catalyst loading, reaction temperature of 151 °C, and reaction time of 4 h under a vacuum. 100 % conversion of sorbitol was observed within 2 h, and an isosorbide yield of about 78 % was achieved after 4 h. The kinetics of the reaction were evaluated, the rate law followed a first-order reaction model, and the reaction rate depended on the concentration of reactant. The Langmuir–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson (LHHW) model was used to determine that the first dehydration was the rate-determining step of this reaction. The study also examined the deactivation of the catalyst using FE-SEM, N2 adsorption/desorption, DSC, TGA, and XPS, confirming that changes to the catalytic properties after the reaction negatively impacted the performance of the sorbitol dehydration reaction. The catalytic performance and kinetic analysis were used to explain the mechanism of the double dehydration of sorbitol into isosorbide, providing essential information for catalyst and isosorbide production process design. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biorefinery Sorbitol Isosorbide Kinetic study Acid resin catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The sustainable production of high-value chemicals shows great promise for replacing existing chemical production processes, which are mainly based on nonrenewable petroleum-based raw materials that cause pollution and are a major source of carbon emissions [1]. Consequently, biomass resources have been promoted as an alternative raw material for the synthesis of many chemicals. Biomass materials derived from cellulose can be used to produce many useful chemicals. For example, sorbitol, a polyol derived from glucose, is a useful product that can be obtained from the hydrolysis and hydrogenation of cellulose. Sorbitol is also considered a molecular platform for further synthetic processes [2,3]. The double dehydration of sorbitol into isosorbide is a major research focus because isosorbide is an important component in applications such as food additives, plasticizers, and chemical building platforms [4,5]. Over the past several decades, the double dehydration of sorbitol has been performed with homogeneous catalysts such as mineral acids (e.g., sulfuric acid and phosphoric acid). However, while high catalytic activity has been obtained with these homogeneous catalysts, they also generate a large amount of pollution and require a separation process to obtain the product [6,7]. Thus, the development of a greener, more sustainable, and productive sorbitol dehydration process would be highly desirable. Recently, sorbitol dehydration research has mainly focused on heterogeneous catalysts that do not require a separation step [8–10]. Some heterogeneous catalyst materials that have been investigated for sorbitol double dehydration include beta zeolites (BEA) [11], sulfated zirconia [12], and sulfated titania [13]. These catalysts have achieved isosorbide yields of up to 70 %. However, although these catalysts can provide satisfactory activity, they require high temperatures of up to 180 °C, high pressures to stabilize the product phase, long reaction times, and large catalyst doses. Strong acid-modified catalysts can also be used, providing yields of up to 85 % under solvent-free and lower-pressure conditions. Examples of these acid-modified catalysts include a mesoporous carbon-based acid catalyst [14], acidified niobium oxide [15], and silver-exchanged phosphotungstic acid [16]. Polymer-based catalysts, such as poly(ionic liquid) solid acid [8], poly(ionic liquid)-covalent organic frameworks [10], and acid resin catalysts (e.g., Amberlyst 36 [17], Amberlyst 15, and Purolite CT269 [18]) have also been reported. Notably, acid resin catalysts can be considered the most convenient high-performance option for large-scale isosorbide production due to their relative stability, large surface area, large particle size, and functional groups. Consequently, acid resins are widely used as dehydration catalysts in several industrial processes [19,20]. A significant disadvantage of heterogeneous sorbitol dehydration catalysts is that they are less catalytically active than homogeneous sorbitol dehydration catalysts at the industrial scale. To overcome this issue, the kinetics of the sorbitol dehydration with heterogeneous catalysts have also been studied to investigate the behavior, rate, and parameters of the reaction. Polaert et al. reported a kinetic study on isosorbide production using Amberlyst 35 as the catalyst [21]. The reaction was performed at 140 °C for 5 h under microwave irradiation and vacuum conditions, and they described the dehydration reaction and the reaction pathway with the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (LH) kinetic model. Kamaruzaman et al. evaluated sorbitol dehydration over Amberlyst 36 in a solvent-free system at 150 °C for 4 h with nitrogen purging [17,22]. They also reported that the LH model described this reaction. However, relying on microwave irradiation or continuous nitrogen purging could lead to large costs in scaled-up industrial processes. Moreover, catalytic deactivation needs to be studied to evaluate the suitability of these heterogeneous catalysts for large-scale production. In this work, the double dehydration of sorbitol into isosorbide was studied using a commercial sulfonic resin catalyst under a vacuum generated by water ejector. Then, a kinetic study on the parametrically optimized conditions was performed to determine the reaction rate and investigate the reaction behavior over the catalyst. Moreover, the reusability and deactivation of the catalyst were studied and investigated by FE-SEM, N2 adsorption/desorption, DSC, TGA/DTG, and XPS. The work reported herein provides guidance for the design of a scaled-up isosorbide production process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials D-sorbitol (99 %) was purchased from Lab Valley Limited Partnership. Purolite CT269 was purchased from Purolite Corporation. Isosorbide (98 %) was obtained from Sigma Aldrich for use as a standard, and 1,4-sorbitan (97 %) was obtained from USP to use in high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis. Deionized water (18.2 MΩ cm) was used as the reaction solvent. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Nitrogen adsorption-desorption was performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460. The specific surface area and average pore size of the catalysts were calculated using the BET and BJH methods, respectively. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) was performed on a JEOL JSM-7001 F with an acceleration voltage of 15 kV to analyze the morphology of the catalyst. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on an FEI Helios NanoLab G3 CX to further evaluate the surface morphology of the catalyst. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis was performed with a NETZSCH DSC 214 Polyma® to evaluate the thermal properties of the catalyst up to 400 °C. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) were performed with a SHIMADZU DTG-60H to analyze the thermal stability of the catalyst up to 900 °C. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was used to analyze the catalyst composition. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ULVAC-PHI, PHI 500 VersaProbe II) was performed with Al Kα radiation as the excitation source to analyze the oxidation states of the catalyst. XPS measurements were conducted at the BL5.3 SUTNANOTEC-SLRI XPS beamline at the Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Thailand. The binding energies were calibrated using the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. 2.3 Catalytic performance Sorbitol dehydration was performed in a 250 mL three-necked flask on a hot plate with a temperature sensor. Using an adapter, a water jet pump was attached to one neck of the flask to create a vacuum for steam removal. The remaining necks were sealed with glass stoppers. The temperature sensor was used to measure and control the reaction temperature. Initially, the D-sorbitol was melted under vacuum at 151 °C for 1 h. After melting, the Purolite CT269 catalyst was added to initiate the reaction. The reaction was performed with 4.43 wt.% catalyst (relative to the D-sorbitol weight), and the reaction mixture was stirred at 500 rpm for 4 h at 151 °C. These reaction conditions were based on the optimized reaction conditions reported by Lertna [23]. After the reaction was finished, the three-necked flask was removed from the hot plate. During the first 2 h of the reaction, a 200 µL sample was collected every 10 min. During the next 1 h, a 200 µL sample was taken every 20 min. Then, for the final 1 h, a 200 µL sample was taken every 30 min. Each sample was diluted with a dilution factor of 50 for HPLC analysis. 2.4 Sample analysis A Waters e2695 HPLC system with a refractive index detector (Waters 2414) and a Phenomenex RezexTM RCM-Monosaccharide Ca+ column (300 × 7.8 mm) was used for HPLC analysis. Product analysis was performed using deionized water with a flow rate of 0.45 mL/min as the mobile phase. Standards of sorbitol (the reactant), 1,4 sorbitan (the intermediate), and isosorbide (the product) were prepared, and these were the compounds detected by the column. Undetected compounds (including 2,6-sorbitan, 2,5-menitan, 2,5-iditan, 1,5-sorbitan, and humin) were assumed to be unknown. The conversion ( C sorbitol ), product yield ( Y product ), and selectivity ( S product ) values were calculated using Eqs. (1)–(3). The percentage of unknown or other products (i.e., the unidentifiable products and polymerization/degradation products of humin) was denoted “Other” and calculated using Eq. (4). (1) C sorbitol ( % ) = N i , sorbitol − N f , sorbitol N i , sorbitol × 100 (2) Y product ( % ) = N product N i , sorbitol × 100 (3) S product ( % ) = N product N i , sorbitol − N f , sorbitol × 100 (4) Other ( % ) = 100 % − S 1 , 4 − sorbitan − S isosorbide where N i , sorbitol is the initial amount of sorbitol (mol), N f , sorbitol is the final amount of sorbitol after the reaction (mol), N product is the amount of generated product (mol), and the subscript “product” refers to 1,4-sorbitan or isosorbide. 2.5 Kinetic study Based on the products identified by HPLC, the double dehydration of sorbitol into isosorbide proceeded via several reaction pathways. In the first dehydration step, sorbitol (SB) was dehydrated into 1,4-sorbitan (ST) and other by-products (Other). In the second dehydration step, 1,4-sorbitan (ST) was converted to isosorbide (ISB). Other by-products were treated as a single species to simplify calculations. Two kinetic models were evaluated: the rate law order models, which describe the reaction by comparing first-order and second-order kinetics, and the Langmuir–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson (LHHW) model, which correlates the kinetic behavior with the surface phenomena involving molecular interactions and the active sites of the catalyst. 2.6 Catalyst reusability and deactivation study After the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reactor through filtration to avoid catalyst loss. Then, the used catalyst was washed with deionized water and dried at 70 °C for 3 h. A subsequent reaction cycle was carried out under the same conditions without any additional fresh catalyst. 3 Results & discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The conversion of sorbitol to isosorbide was analyzed in detail, and the concentration profiles of each component in the reaction are shown in Fig. 1 . The carbon balance refers to the molar percentages of carbon present in the sorbitol and the products (1,4-sorbitan and isosorbide) formed during the reaction. Sorbitol conversion continually increased with increasing reaction time, and 100 % conversion was achieved after 2 h. This was accompanied by the production of 1,4-sorbitan, whose yield increased up to 37 % at about 1.3 h. After this point, the yield of 1,4-sorbitan decreased, indicating that 1,4-sorbitan is likely the intermediate utilized by the second dehydration reaction step to produce isosorbide. As the second dehydration step proceeded, the yield of 1,4-sorbitan decreased while that of isosorbide increased. After 4 h, the final yield of isosorbide was about 78 %, while the yield of the intermediate 1,4-sorbitan was almost zero. 3.2 Reaction mechanism The production of isosorbide from sorbitol proceeds via a two-step pathway mechanism. Theoretically, this reaction can be explained in terms of an intramolecular reaction with a substitution nucleophilic bimolecular (SN2) reaction in which one end of the molecule is removed [6,24–26]. Considering the catalytic performance, the reaction mechanism for the first dehydration step is described as shown in Fig. 2 a. First, a proton or hydrogen ion (H+) from the acid catalyst directly reacts with the hydroxyl group (OH) at the C1 position of sorbitol. This causes the formation and release of water (H2O). Consequently, a cyclization reaction occurs between the C1 and C4 positions, forming a tetrahydrofuran ring with OH trans-linked on the C4 position. Thus, 1,4-sorbitan is generated by the first dehydration step as the intermediate. Alternatively, protonation can also occur at the C6 position, as shown in Fig. 2b. This leads to the formation of 3,6-sorbitan, which is another potential intermediate. However, 3,6-sorbitan was not able to be investigated in this experiment. The pathway for the second dehydration step is shown in Fig. 3 . H+ protonates the C4 position of 1,4-sorbitan or the C3 position of 3,6-sorbitan, causing the release of H2O and another cyclization reaction. Consequently, the hexahydrofuro structure is formed with two alcohols or diols at the C3 and C6 positions, leading to the generation of isosorbide as the product [27,28]. Bonnin et al. reported that no other products were detected during the reaction of 1,4-sorbitan and 3,6-sorbitan using a Brønsted acid catalyst. This finding confirms that these sorbitan compounds do not undergo any reactions other than their conversion to isosorbide, although some of the isosorbide decomposes into humin [29]. Under the optimum reaction conditions, the concentration of each component was evaluated using HPLC, as shown in Fig. 4 . The first dehydration of sorbitol led to the formation of the intermediate 1,4-sorbitan, and in the second dehydration step, 1,4-sorbitan was converted into isosorbide. Undesired or unknown products, referred to as “Other”, were also produced during the first dehydration. Other studies have mainly identified these secondary products as 2,5-sorbitan (protonated at the C5 position and cyclized at the C2 position) and 1,5-sorbitan (protonated at the C1 position and cyclized at the C5 position). These two secondary products each consist of a tetrahydrofuran ring at the center with a linked hydroxyl group, and they remain stable in the product solution [25,29–31]. 3.3 Power-law rate To study the kinetics of this dehydration reaction with respect to substrate concentration, first order and second-order rate law models were employed. In the first-order model, the concentration of the reactant decreases exponentially over time, resulting in a reaction rate that is linearly dependent on the reactant concentration. Conversely, in the second-order model, the reaction rate decreases more rapidly because it is quadratically dependent on the reactant concentration. For the purposes of this comparison, the following assumptions have been made to simplify the reaction analysis, based on the reaction mechanism and concentration profiles: 1. The pathway of the reaction consists of the conversion of sorbitol into 1,4-sorbitan followed by the conversion of 1,4-sorbitan into isosorbide. 2. The second dehydration reaction is irreversible. 3. The degradation and polymerization rates of the reactant, product, and by-products are negligible. 4. The by-products, which include 1,5-sorbitan, 2,5-sorbitan, and humin, are defined as a single product denoted “Other”. Linear regression was used to calculate the rate constants of the simplified reaction pathway (Fig. 5 ), and calculations were performed with POLYMATH 6.10 Educational Version. A first-order reaction was considered, as shown in Eqs. (5)–(8): (5) d C SB d t = − k 1 C SB − k 3 C SB (6) d C ST d t = k 1 C SB − k 2 C ST (7) d C ISB dt = k 2 C ST (8) d C Other d t = k 3 C SB where C S B is the concentration of sorbitol, C S T is the concentration of 1,4-sorbitan, C I S B is the concentration of isosorbide, C Other is the concentration of other species, k 1 is the rate constant of the dehydration of sorbitol to 1,4-sorbitan, k 2 is the rate constant of the dehydration of 1,4-sorbitan to isosorbide, and k 3 is the rate constant of the dehydration of sorbitol to other products. The first-order reaction is expressed in Eq. (9). (9) ln C t = − k × t + ln C 0 where C t is the concentration of any species at a specific reaction time ( t ) and C 0 is the concentration of any species at the beginning of the reaction ( t = 0 ). A comparison of the experimental concentration data and concentrations calculated using the first-order model is shown in Fig. 6 a. The R 2 values are 0.9803 for sorbitol, 0.7331 for 1,4-sorbitan, 0.9840 for isosorbide, and 0.9486 for other products. The rate constants k 1 , k 2 , and k 3 have values of 0.8889, 0.9531, and 0.3252 h−1, respectively. Rate constant k 2 has the highest value, indicating that the second dehydration of 1,4-sorbitan into isosorbide is the most rapid step in this reaction. A second-order reaction model was also considered, as defined in Eqs. (10)–(13): (10) d C SB d t = − k 1 C SB 2 − k 3 C SB 2 (11) d C ST d t = k 1 C SB 2 − k 2 C ST 2 (12) d C ISB d t = k 2 C ST 2 (13) d C Other d t = k 3 C SB 2 where the variables have the same definitions as those of the first-order model. The second-order reaction model was defined as expressed in Eq. (14): (14) 1 C t = k × t + 1 C 0 A comparison of the second-order model with the experimental data is shown in Fig. 6b. The calculated rate constants k 1 , k 2 , and k 3 of the second-order model are 0.0018, 0.0024, and 0.0012 h−1, respectively. Like the first-order model, the second dehydration step has the highest rate constant value. However, the second-order model does not fit the data very well, with lower R2 values of 0.8305 for sorbitol, 0.0131 for 1,4-sorbitan, 0.7686 for isosorbide, and 0.4854 for other products. The Mears criterion ( C M ) was used to check if the reaction was limited by external diffusion, as outlined in Eq. (15). (15) C M = − r S B , o b s ρ c a t R n k c C SB , b where r S B , o b s represents the reaction rate of sorbitol, n denotes the reaction order, R is the catalyst particle radius, ρ cat indicates the bulk density of the catalyst, C S B , b refers to the bulk concentration of sorbitol, and k c is the mass transfer coefficient. When C M < 0.15, external mass transfer effects are negligible. Additionally, the Weisz-Prater parameter (CWP) was employed to assess the significance of internal diffusion resistance during SB dehydration, as shown in Eq. (16). (16) C WP = − r S B , o b s ρ c a t R 2 D e C SB , S where D e represents the effective diffusivity and C SB , S denotes the concentration of sorbitol in the mixture. When C WP ≪ 1 , there are no internal diffusion limitations, resulting in the absence of a concentration gradient within the catalyst particles. However, when C WP ≫ 1 , internal diffusion imposes significant limitations on the reaction. In this work, C M was calculated to be 1.13 × 10–10 and C WP was 4.22 × 10–10. Therefore, external and internal mass transfer were negligible and did not impose limitations on this reaction. The double dehydration of sorbitol using Purolite CT269 as the catalyst under the optimal reaction conditions is more accurately described by the first-order reaction model, and mass transfer is not rate-limiting. According to this model, the reaction rate depends on the concentration of sorbitol, and the first dehydration proceeds via the formation of 1,4-sorbitan as the intermediate. Notably, the delay of 1,4-sorbitan in the actual experiment compared to the calculation profile could potentially be ascribed to the low desorption rate of 1,4-sorbitan after the first dehydration of sorbitol, as illustrated in Fig. 6(a). This second dehydration step had the highest rate constant and provides isosorbide as the product. The Arrhenius equation was used to evaluate the activation energy (Ea) of the double dehydration reaction, as expressed in Eq. (17): (17) k = A × e − E a R T where k is the rate constant (h−1), A is the pre-exponential factor, E a is the activation energy (J/mol), R is the ideal gas constant (8.314 J/mol K), and T is the reaction temperature (K). A linear form of this equation can be obtained by taking the natural logarithm of both sides, as shown in Eq. (18): (18) ln k = ( − E a R ) ( 1 T ) + ln A The Arrhenius plot for the simplified reaction pathway (Fig. 5) using the first-order model rate constants is shown in Fig. 7 . The apparent activation energies are 84.66 kJ/mol for the dehydration of sorbitol to 1,4-sorbitan ( E a 1 ), 79.63 kJ/mol for the dehydration of 1,4-sorbitan to isosorbide ( E a 2 ), and 37.86 kJ/mol for the dehydration of sorbitol to other products ( E a 3 ). The R2 values of these three steps are 0.9975, 0.9662, and 0.9599, respectively. These results indicate that the first dehydration step has the highest activation energy, meaning that the dehydration of sorbitol into 1,4-sorbitan has a higher energy barrier than the second dehydration and the side reaction steps. Moreover, the activation energies for various catalysts were compared. The reaction without a catalyst exhibited activation energies of E a 1 = 127 kJ/mol and E a 2 = 195 kJ/mol [25]. The use of the Purolite CT269 catalyst significantly reduced the activation energies by approximately 33.34 % and 60.70 %, respectively, as shown in Table 1 . This Purolite CT269 catalyst demonstrated lower activation energies in both dehydration reaction steps compared to Amberlyst 36 and NbOPO4. However, compared to silico-tungstic acid (a more acidic catalyst), the Ea1 value of Purolite CT269 was lower while the Ea2 value was higher. Compared to Amberlyst 35, which has a larger surface area, Purolite CT269 exhibited higher activation energies [17,21,32,33]. Overall, using Purolite CT269 to catalyze the dehydration of sorbitol into isosorbide in this work resulted in satisfactory reaction performance in terms of isosorbide yield under vacuum conditions. 3.4 Langmuir–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson model To describe the kinetics of a heterogeneous catalytic reaction in more detail, the adsorption-desorption behavior on the surface of the catalyst needs to be taken into account [35,36]. The Langmuir–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson model (LHHW) is a kinetic model that is commonly used to obtain rate expressions for catalytic reactions over heterogeneous catalysts. Using this model, the adsorption and desorption of reactants, intermediates, and products on the catalyst surface are considered. In the ideal adsorption layer in this mode, reactants are transferred to identical surface sites. To determine the rate-determining step, which is the slowest step of the reaction that limits the overall reaction rate, the sorbitol dehydration reaction was evaluated from the adsorption step through the desorption step. Physical transport steps such as external and internal diffusion were ignored. Thus, the steps of the double dehydration of sorbitol in the LHHW model are as follows: SB + S ↔ k 1 , L , k 2 , L SB − S ( Adsorption / desorption of sorbitol ) SB − S + S → k 3 , L ST − S + Other − S ( Surface reaction : sorbitol to 1 , 4 − sorbitan and other ) ST − S ↔ k 4 , L , k 5 , L ST + S ( Adsorption / desorption of 1 , 4 − sorbitan ) ST − S + S → k 6 , L ISB − S ( Surface reaction : 1 , 4 − sorbitan to isosorbide ) ISB − S ↔ k 7 , L , k 8 , L ISB + S ( Desorption of isosorbide ) Other − S ↔ k 9 , L , k 10 , L Other + S ( Desorption of other by − products ) The reaction equation for the LHHW model was obtained using the same assumptions as those made for the power-rate law model. Some additional assumptions were also made, as follows: 1. The reaction was conducted under high-temperature and vacuum conditions, ensuring the rapid removal of generated water from the catalyst surface. As a result, no water remains attached to the catalyst surface during the reaction. 2. k2,L >> k3,L (the rate constant for the desorption of sorbitol is much higher than the reaction rate constant of sorbitol to 1,4-sorbitan). 3. k4,L >> k6,L (the rate constant for the desorption of 1,4-sorbitan is much higher than the reaction rate constant of 1,4-sorbitan to isosorbide). Nonlinear regression analysis using POLYMATH 6.10 was used to evaluate the rate expression based on the initial rate and concentration of each species. The experimental and calculated reaction rates for the surface reaction of sorbitol to 1,4-sorbitan (i.e., the first dehydration step) are well-correlated, with an R2 value of 0.9705 (Fig. 8 ). This is higher than the R2 values of the 1,4-sorbitan adsorption-desorption step (0.0560), the second dehydration reaction (0.7461), the isosorbide adsorption-desorption step (0.0209), and the other products adsorption-desorption step (0.2227). Therefore, the first dehydration was determined to be the rate-limiting step. The rate of this surface reaction is expressed in Eq. (19): (19) r a = k 3 , L × ( k 1 , L k 2 , L × C a ) × [ S 0 1 + ( k 1 , L k 2 , L × C a ) + ( k 5 , L k 6 , L × C b ) + ( k 6 , L k 5 , L k 7 , L k 4 , L × C b ) + ( k 8 , L k 7 , L × C c ) + ( k 10 , L k 9 , L × C d ) ] 2 where r a is the rate of the reaction, C i is the concentration of species i (where subscripts a, b, c, and d represent sorbitol, 1,4-sorbitan, isosorbide, and other, respectively), k is the rate constant of each reaction step, and S 0 is the concentration of free sites. Based on this calculation, the reaction rate was described by the Langmuir-Hinshelwood model, as shown in Eq. (20): (20) r a = ( 67.80 × C a ) × [ 30.02 1 + ( 0.35 × C a ) + ( 4.42 × C b ) + ( 0.99 × C c ) − ( 4.2 × C d ) ] 2 Therefore, considering the adsorption-desorption equilibrium of the double dehydration of sorbitol over Purolite CT269, the first dehydration step is the rate-limiting step of the overall reaction. This indicates that the overall reaction cannot proceed more rapidly than the generation of 1,4-sorbitan from sorbitol. Moreover, this result is in good agreement with the calculated activation energies, which show that the first dehydration step requires the highest activation energy. 3.5 Catalyst reusability and deactivation Catalytic stability is crucial for industrial-scale processes. Therefore, a reusability experiment was performed under the same conditions to determine the stability of the Purolite CT269 catalyst. After each cycle, the spent catalyst was removed through vacuum filtration to ensure complete recovery, washed with 60 °C deionized water, and dried at 80 °C for 3 h. The next cycle was performed without the addition of any fresh catalyst, and the results are displayed in Fig. 9 . A loss of catalytic activity was observed with increasing cycle number. After four reaction cycles, the conversion of sorbitol declined from 100 % to about 60 %. Moreover, the yield of isosorbide declined from 60 % to 15 %. The 1,4-sorbitan yield slightly increased to about 40 % in the third reaction cycle and then declined in the fourth cycle. These results demonstrate the deactivation of the catalyst with increasing use. SEM images of the fresh and spent catalyst (after four cycles) are shown in Fig. 10 . The shape of the catalyst did not significantly change after the reaction. However, the appearance of scratches was potentially caused by the mechanical force of the magnetic stirrer. The specific surface area, pore width, and pore volume before and after the reaction were investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption, as reported in Table 2 . The fresh catalyst had a surface area of 34.53 m2/g, while the surface area significantly declined to 17.86 m2/g after four cycles. The pore width declined from 33.64 to 31.06 nm, and the pore volume declined from 7.93 to 4.10 cm3/g. This was potentially attributed to the coverage of the catalyst surface with humin, which could be generated by the degradation/polymerization of the reactant, product, or by-products of the dehydration reaction. Alternatively, the catalyst structure was potentially affected by the reaction conditions. The polymeric structural stability of the catalyst was further evaluated by DSC and TGA, which were used to identify differences between the fresh catalyst and the catalyst obtained after four reaction cycles. DSC curves of the fresh and spent catalyst were obtained in the range of 0 to 350 °C, as shown in Fig. 11 . The endothermic peak located at about 100 °C was attributed to moisture removal. The glass transition of the fresh catalyst occurred in the range of 271.3 to 304.7 °C, but a corresponding transition was not observed in the spent catalyst. TG curves were obtained from 30 to 700 °C, as shown in Fig. 12 . The DTG peak located below 100 °C in both curves was ascribed to water removal. The change in mass observed at about 270 °C corresponded to the DSC analysis. For the fresh catalyst, the TGA peak at 271.68 °C was ascribed to glass transition or the thermal degradation of polystyrene within Purolite CT269. This was in agreement with the DSC analysis and other literature. Pfaffli et al. reported that polystyrene degradation begins at about 270 °C [37]. The glass transition of the spent catalyst was indicated by the small DTG peak at 269.76 °C, although this glass transition was not observed in the DSC curve. The TG curves of both the fresh and spent catalysts showed a loss of mass up to about 500 °C, with DTG peaks in the range of 400 to 500 °C ascribed to the decomposition of crosslinking divinylbenzene groups. This was in agreement with the results reported by Li et al. [38]. The main exothermic in this temperature range was located at about 460 °C for the fresh catalyst, and this peak was shifted to about 430 °C for the spent catalyst. Li et al. proposed that the thermal stability of polystyrene-type beads increases with increasing crosslinking degree, which means that a lower degree of crosslinking provides lower thermal stability. Therefore, these results indicate that the sorbitol dehydration reaction potentially led to the decomposition of crosslinking groups in the catalyst. Moreover, an exothermic peak was observed at about 480 °C in the DTG curves of both the fresh and spent catalyst, which was attributed to the decomposition of sulfonic acid functional groups in the catalyst. After using the catalyst 3 times, the sulfonic acid surface content of the catalyst might be lower. In summary, these results confirm that the structural properties of the Purolite CT269 catalyst changed after the reaction. The loss of the crosslinking agent from the polymeric structure of the catalyst led to lower thermal stability and the loss of functional groups, which negatively affected the catalytic performance for the sorbitol dehydration reaction. XPS was used to further evaluate the surface chemical state of the fresh and spent catalysts. The full survey spectra were obtained in the binding energy range of 0 to 1400 eV, as displayed in Fig. 13 . These full survey spectra (Fig. 13(a) and (b)) showed the presence of C, O, and S elements in both the fresh and spent catalysts. After the reaction, the relative intensities of these signals significantly changed. The deconvolution of the S 2p3/2 spectra revealed four distinct peaks, as illustrated in Fig. 14 (a) and (b). This analysis suggests that the most common sulfur species in the fresh catalyst were S2O3 2− (169.14 eV) and CSO3 H (168.55 eV) [39]. After reaction, there was a significant decline in intensity, with the majority of the remaining sulfur being attributed to the CSO2 C peak at 168.19 eV [40]. This observation implies that sulfur was lost during the dehydration of sorbitol, potentially due to the structural collapse of the polymeric catalyst. Consequently, this remaining sulfur was located beneath the humin by-product layer, resulting in a higher proportion of CSO2 C bonds. To confirm the generation of humin on the catalyst, the C 1s spectra of the fresh and spent catalysts were deconvoluted, as shown in Fig. 14(c) and (d). The fresh catalyst showed three peaks, including a large peak ascribed to the significant presence of adventitious carbon (CC, COH) at 284.85 eV and smaller peaks related to organic carboxylic acid (COH) or ether (COC) groups at 286.06 eV and carbonyl groups (CO) at 287.40 eV [41]. After the reaction, a peak ascribed to carbonyl groups (OCO) at 288.09 eV was also observed, and the intensity of the peak ascribed to COH or COC significantly grew in intensity relative to the adventitious carbon peak, indicating the more polar surface C group of humin [42]. The O 1s spectra were deconvoluted to better identify the carbon species, as shown in Fig. 14(e) and (f). The fresh catalyst showed three peaks: the COC bond peak at 532.89 eV was ascribed to an aliphatic structure, the CO signal at 533.84 eV was attributed to acid anhydride ((CO*)O(CO*)), and the HOH bond peak at 534.48 eV was attributed to the adsorbed water on the catalyst surface [41]. The spent catalyst showed the same species in addition to OCO and COC bonds from an aromatic structure at 533.36 eV. This indicated the generation of a complex carbon (humin) layer on the catalyst. The generation of this humin layer could block the active sites, leading to lower catalytic activity. Unfortunately, the catalyst experienced dramatic deactivation, limiting the potential for reuse in subsequent catalytic cycles. During the batch reaction process, the products and by-products remained in the system for up to 4 h. Consequently, the catalyst became coated with humin, reducing its catalytic efficiency. Future work should evaluate strategies for mitigating or preventing this catalyst deactivation. For instance, catalysts can be designed or modified to prevent the generation of complex carbon. This can be accomplished through hydrophobic functionalization using hydrophobic agents such as 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxysilane (3-MPTMS) [43], trimethylchlorosilane (TMCS) [44], ethyltriethoxysilane (ETES), or iso-octyltrimethoxysilane (Iso-OTMS) [45]. Zhang J. et al. reported that the superhydrophobic modification of a mesoporous acid catalyst enabled the extension of cycling times and facilitated the easier removal of humin from the catalyst surface, although the formation of coke or humin was not completely avoidable. Another potential strategy for addressing catalytic deactivation is the implementation of a continuous flow system, which would enable the continuous removal of the products and by-products. Thus, the surface of the catalyst would not be coated with humin [30,46,47]. 5 Conclusion In this work, the kinetics of the double dehydration of sorbitol into isosorbide were studied over an acid resin catalyst, and the stability of the catalyst was also evaluated. The reaction was performed using 4.43 wt.% Purolite CT269 catalyst at 151 °C for 4 h under vacuum conditions, resulting in the complete conversion of sorbitol and an isosorbide yield of more than 80 %. The reaction is dependent on the concentration of the reactant, while mass transfer is not a limiting factor. The activation energy of the first dehydration step (sorbitol to 1,4-sorbitan) is higher than that of the second dehydration step (1,4-sorbitan to isosorbide) and parallel side reactions. Moreover, the Langmuir–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson (LHHW) model shows that the first dehydration is the rate-determining step for isosorbide production. This confirms that the overall reaction cannot proceed faster than the generation of the intermediate species 1,4-sorbitan. Furthermore, catalyst deactivation was investigated, revealing that the structural properties of the catalyst were altered following the reaction. The loss of the crosslinking agent negatively affected thermal stability, and the formation of a complex humin layer on the catalyst reduced the catalytic performance for the sorbitol dehydration reaction. This result provides essential information for catalyst and process design for the dehydration of sorbitol to isosorbide, contributing to the broader development of biomass valorization processes. coredata.dc:description: Biomass-derived chemicals show great promise as an alternative resource for the replacement of fossil fuel-derived chemicals. The double dehydration of sorbitol produces isosorbide, which is an important chemical building platform and a component in food, pharmaceuticals, and plasticizers. Homogeneous catalysts are used to perform this reaction due to their good performance, but they also exhibit some drawbacks. Therefore, in this study, the sulfonic acid resin Purolite CT269 was used as a heterogeneous catalyst to study isosorbide production. The reaction was carried out with a 4.43 wt.% catalyst loading, reaction temperature of 151 °C, and reaction time of 4 h under a vacuum. 100 % conversion of sorbitol was observed within 2 h, and an isosorbide yield of about 78 % was achieved after 4 h. The kinetics of the reaction were evaluated, the rate law followed a first-order reaction model, and the reaction rate depended on the concentration of reactant. The Langmuir–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson (LHHW) model was used to determine that the first dehydration was the rate-determining step of this reaction. The study also examined the deactivation of the catalyst using FE-SEM, N2 adsorption/desorption, DSC, TGA, and XPS, confirming that changes to the catalytic properties after the reaction negatively impacted the performance of the sorbitol dehydration reaction. The catalytic performance and kinetic analysis were used to explain the mechanism of the double dehydration of sorbitol into isosorbide, providing essential information for catalyst and isosorbide production process design.
